posts.name: Bob Wolff - Janksters Team 1967
posts.cooked:
Hey all - I’m a mentor for Team 1967 - The Janksters. We’re moving to Java this year and I’ve run into a question as I try to help organize things pre-season. The default folder structure for a Java sample/example project is:

The example code then lies in the robot folder and calls itself “package frc.robot”

The WPI libraries are hanging out in ~/wpilib//maven and there seems to be no issue with doing:

Great!

Now for the trouble …

I want to organize our codebase such that we can have classes and libraries which live at the same folder level as  and also above  to allow for classes which get used by several projects in a given year as well as classes which get re-used year after year. Something like the following:

I’ve been hunting all over the gradle settings and such and haven’t had success yet. Can some experienced Java person help me understand how I can modify a project this way? It seems quite possible given that the WPI libraries are in a different location and they don’t have trouble but I don’t see a clear reference to WPI in terms of “class path”.

Thanks! –bob

posts.name: connor.worley
posts.cooked: I think you want to look Into gradle subprojects and declare a subproject->subproject dependency from your robot code to the utility code. See Declaring Dependencies between Subprojects

posts.name: Bob Wolff - Janksters Team 1967
posts.cooked:
Thanks for the thought and the pointer, Connor. I’m hoping there’s a simpler answer, frankly, as the WPI libraries are being picked up without an issue and whatever the mechanism is for that “classpath” would seem to suit my needs as well for adding two more paths relative to a project location.

Anyone know how the WPI library classpath mechanism is facilitated?

Thanks, –bob

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
The WPILib libraries are pulled in as a maven dependency. So they’re grabbed from the internet (Or a local cache on your computer) and pulled in.

You can publish your own maven packages, but thats definitely not “simple” at all.

The standard gradle way to do what you’re wanting to do is a subproject.

The other option is to just make separate folders in src/main/java . And in there you could put your separate code, and each would be considered its own package. Everything would just get compiled together all at once.

posts.name: Bob Wolff - Janksters Team 1967
posts.cooked:
Thad - thanks for addressing the mechanism for WPILib. I was hopeful there was a simple answer there to use as a “springboard” for my need. I’ll look into the subproject item that you and Connor both reference. Hopefully that isn’t too intricate.

While I do realize I could copy the files into src/main/java, that leaves me with multiple copies of those library files over time and a heck of a versioning mess I just don’t want the team to have to deal with.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
Yeah, there is no simple answer, which is part of the reason we don’t have anything officially part of the wpilib documentation, and why when you import a project between years it always makes a copy of the code. Theres a million ways to do project separation, and theres pros and cons to all of them. Basically all of them require you to have gradle knowledge, and how java packaging works in general.

Java at least is simpler then C++. Java you can do standard gradle things, which there is a lot of documentations and guides for. The C++ setup is much more picky, and doing separated builds requires a lot of domain specific knowledge.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Jitpack is a good choice for small scale projects like this.

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: As Oblarg mentioned JitPack is a good option but if you are looking for something not using something like that you can just package a jar and add it to gradle with implementation files('libs/lib-1.0.jar') .

posts.name: connor.worley
posts.cooked: Another alternative is to define the utility as another library component in your build.gradle rather than dealing with subprojects. We do that with spdlog for C++, and I imagine you could do something similar with Java.

posts.name: Bob Wolff - Janksters Team 1967
posts.cooked: Connor - I like the sound of this the most. These two other locations are basically libraries. Can you share what you had to change in C+±land? I’d love to see if I can adapt that to our Java project. I looked at the docs on subprojects and frankly it was much more intricate and involved that I’d hoped for.

posts.name: connor.worley
posts.cooked:
Sure, the only change besides the library definition I linked above is the lib library: 'spdlog', linkage: 'static' dependency declaration on line 111.

It looks like things are different in Java-land, but I see this example defining an javaArtifact instead of an frcJavaArtifact . Maybe someone on here knows how to declare dependencies under that artifact dsl.

Or, yet another alternative, maybe someone knows how to simply add additional sources to the frcJavaArtifact you already have.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
One thing to think about is whether it’s reasonable to have a library that works for multiple year’s robots. That takes discipline to avoid breaking things. Also, if your library depends on WPILib, then when you update the library to the next year’s WPILib, you’d need to update each robot also. Depending on how you do your library, you can work around this with versioning, but it’s something to think about

We ended up with a library, but it was fairly limited in scope, primarily supporting specific devices or extensions of WPILib classes. We also had a lot of common code for subsystems and commands, but that was copy and pasted because there was generally logic that ended up being customized and making generic was more trouble then it was worth.

Here’s our library that was published with jitpack. https://github.com/Beachbot330/BeachbotLib
